text: actually the way we met was through michael which i alluded to and michael met you through dns yeah i was at i think exercise two when i met him january right before like a couple weeks before i met you actually so talk to me about then your foreign to dynamic neuromuscular stabilization um you know i didn't i never super like did a deep dive into dns um i thought the positions were great i love you know how you use your developmental patterns from three months to walking i i love kind of reverse engineering that and putting people in some of those positions i think it's great um i i love the the talk about developmental you know just skills and how we lose them as we start moving around um this um you know i have three kids and my youngest is three and i'm sure my other two did the same thing but i didn't have an eye for it but now that i've been into dns for two years watching my three-year-old move it's like being at a dns seminar with the world's best teacher right he is like a little prodigy he's a little he's like a little prague school prodigy and i just can't believe it i just can't believe how innately these kids load perfectly and move perfectly and do so efficiently right like you watch him get up from a from a position without using his hands just rolling his load from the greater trochanter down the femur over to the knee and boom he's up and it's like he didn't even miss a beat yeah and you just think that the fact that we are born with that
title: Dynamic Neuromuscular Stabilization (DNS) | Peter Attia, M.D. & Beth Lewis

text: neuromuscular control is so humbling is so remarkable is such a testament to evolution right and to think we flush it down the toilet by the time a kid is six years old right yeah because they're not they're missing out on the chance to roll around on the floor anymore after they go to school yeah yeah it's i mean that's what we're designed to do move around efficiently and then once you stop it's it stops it's amazing when you look at people as adults and think how did we possibly come from kids like that and and i guess for people who don't know much about dns uh and you know at some point i i will absolutely be doing a dedicated podcast to that as well um but basically it you know it came from a school in prague that initially i believe was interested in understanding how kids with cerebral palsy cerebral palsy could be trained right or retrained to move by going back and teaching them developmental steps that they missed based on what kids without cp learned so it started out as really a pt school that said hey kids with cp missed this step from from a neurologic standpoint and that's what's completely impaired their movement pattern as adults what if we can as kids train them to do the the non-see you know to do the kids without cp do and from there of course it then morphed into wait we could this is a school of thinking that can help people without cp right um and so through that lens i've you know i found it to be just you know remarkable um but again going back to the way i sort of introduced you most people i interact with are practitioners of one discipline
title: Dynamic Neuromuscular Stabilization (DNS) | Peter Attia, M.D. & Beth Lewis

text: right they are very steeped in x very steeped in y or very steeped in z you don't claim to be the world's expert in any of these things but you like to borrow from all of them including many we won't get to so now let's talk you know fast forward to where we are now which is um you know you're the interloper who's taken from these systems you know and and you and i have had many discussions and maybe you'd like to share there are aspects of each of these systems you actually don't find particularly helpful um is there any that stand out that you're like you know for the work i do i don't think this aspect of pri or frc or dns is helpful um i i don't think you're going to offend anyone i know you're worried about that um i i think that i like to look at the human that i'm working with and you know sometimes doing cars is not what they need you know what i mean so they might need more distal control more distal load tolerance they might need just to control their rib cage so then and they're hyper stressed and i call them hot with anxiety they might need to just lay down and breathe to kind of tap into that parasympathetic side that pri would give you sometimes people need to be upregulated so doing a higher intensity palin rail would be great but nothing's a one size fits all because we're all so different this podcast is for general informational purposes only and does not constitute the practice of medicine nursing or other professional health care services including the giving of
